instruction: What kind of degrees are available at IMT Mines Alès?
output: IMT Mines Alès is part of the prestigious Institute Mines-Télécom. It offers bachelor, master, and doctoral degrees in various fields including Civil Engineering, Engineering of Materials and Mechanics, Information Engineering, Management of Risks and Environment, System and Production Engineering, and Mining.

instruction: Do I need a French credit card?
output: You do not need to have it. However, the card required to ease your life in France will be provided when you open a bank account during the first week, which includes a credit card.

instruction: Do I need French social insurance?
output: Yes, French social insurance is mandatory in France. You will be instructed in the beginning of your study during the first week, with the help of the administrative staff.

instruction: How do I get to the university?
output: IMT Mines Alès is located in southern France between the Cévennes National Park and the Mediterranean Sea, about 70 km from Montpellier-Méditerranée airport. The university is accessible by several highways and by rail, with links to the TGV high-speed train network in neighboring Nîmes. Nearby airports include Nîmes and Marseille.

instruction: Am I allowed to work as a student?
output: Yes, it’s allowed, however, it is difficult to find part-time jobs in Alès due to courses running from Monday to Friday and the low number of touristic activities (e.g., restaurants in Alès or nearby).

instruction: Where do I find information about the things that must be considered before arrival?
output: The studies start in early October each year. We recommend arriving 3-4 days before the starting date to settle. During the first week, the administrative staff will assist you with formalities like insurance, banking, and immigration.

instruction: Where do I have to go first when I arrive in Alès?
output: You have to inform us (two weeks in advance) about your flight schedule and we’ll provide you some information about the travel from Paris to the University. In some cases, we’ll also be able to pick you up at the Alès Railway station.

instruction: Does the university have accommodation on the campus?
output: Yes, the student accommodation is managed by the Alumni (the Association of former students of IMT Mines Alès). The student accommodation includes both houses and several communal areas with a laundry room, washing machines, dryers, games room, television room, etc. The accommodation is around 2.2 km from the IMT Mines Alès campus, with easy access by foot, bus, or bicycle. A bus service is also available at certain times. Parking is secured by security cameras and requires a student card for access.

instruction: Is there a canteen at the university?
output: Yes, there are two places to eat at the University (café and canteen). The canteen provides meals, and vegetarian options are available. University facilities offer good value for money.

instruction: What is it advised to bring with ourselves for accommodation?
output: An internet cable and bed sheet for a single bed are required when you arrive at your student residence.

instruction: Where can I buy essential items?
output: There are several stores in Alès, where you can buy all necessary items you need. The closest shopping center is about 2 km from the student residence (walking distance). There are also second-hand stores available in the city.

instruction: What is the accommodation like?
output: The rooms are individual and include a single bed, a wardrobe, a desk, a bathroom with shower, sink, and toilet. Some rooms in the student accommodation are also equipped with kitchenettes. There are three types of rooms (simplex, duplex, and studios), with prices differing based on size and equipment. Accommodation costs about €400 per month, and scholarships may be available.

instruction: What is the cost of living like for students living in IMT Mines Alès?
output: The living expenses in Alès are about €500 per month (including rent and food). The total living expenses should not exceed €7,000 per year. Accommodation scholarships covering 50% of rent may be available.

instruction: Where can I find the most up-to-date information about master program courses?
output: You can find information on social media like Facebook or on the Master Damage course website: http://master-disaster-management.com and https://www.mines-ales.fr.

instruction: If a student wishes to do a doctorate, can he follow it directly after this master?
output: Yes, the MSc offers the opportunity to do a thesis directly after this one.

instruction: How many holidays are there during the two years?
output: The intake is in early October. There are three weeks of Christmas vacation, one week in February, and one week in April. Classes end in mid-June for Year 1. Year 2 classes end at the end of February.

instruction: The payment is annual; can it be shared in several stages?
output: The payment is done in two installments: year 1 and year 2 before the end of August. However, the payment for each year can also be done in two stages.

instruction: Materials for studies, books, stationery, etc. is included in the annual payment or must be paid in addition?
output: Access to library books is free. There is no obligation to pay fees for access to professors’ documents. All the slides (PPT) of the teachers are in free access for the pupils.

instruction: Are there national or international visits and are they included in the annual fees?
output: There are national visits (especially under module 4) but the cost is taken by IMT Mines Alès.

instruction: Lab fees are included?
output: Students will have access to the computer room. The cost is included in the registration fee.

instruction: The insurance you offer includes repatriation in case of disaster?
output: Repatriation insurance is mandatory in year 2.

instruction: What are the entry requirements for the Master Disaster Management and Environmental Impact?
output: All students must apply on the platform: https://msc.mines-telecom.asia where they can upload the profile (CV, copy passport, 2 letters of recommendation). Applicants must hold a 4-year Bachelor of Science degree in the field of engineering (chemistry, mechanics, environmental sciences, logistics), or have 10 years of industry experience.

instruction: What English language qualifications do I need? Will my English be tested?
output: Proven English proficiency is required through either: native language, Bachelors’ degree taught in English, or English proficiency tests such as TOEFL IBT 105, IELTS 6.5, TOEIC 800, or Cambridge CAE. Your language level will be identified during an interview. There is no mandatory French for the Master Damage, but if you are looking for a part-time job, French is required.

instruction: What is the language of teaching?
output: The whole Master Damage is instructed in English. Teaching and grading for all classes are taught in English within small groups. Some French courses are offered for students during the first semester.

instruction: Can I visit the university before the intake?
output: Yes, it’s possible. Please contact admission-damage@mines-ales.org to arrange an appointment.

instruction: Do I have to take exams during my courses? What kind of exams? When are the exams?
output: Exams are conducted in English as well. Yes, there will be exams throughout the course. The whole Master Disaster Management program consists of 10 modules, including oral, verbal exams, and case study presentations at the end of each module. The program includes 120 ECTS credits: M1 year (60 credits) and M2 year (30 credits). A Master internship (6 months, 30 credits) is also mandatory.

instruction: Once I completed my studies, when do I have my transcript?
output: The provisional transcript is available quickly after completion. The final official document is available a few months after the completion of studies.

instruction: What can I do after I have graduated?
output: Graduates of the Disaster Management MSc will be equipped with the skills and knowledge to seek employment in areas like emergency planning, hazard analysis, catastrophe analysis, humanitarian aid, environmental geography, research, or PhD studies. Common roles include Disaster Recovery Manager, Emergency Coordinator, and Disaster Program Manager.

instruction: Is it possible to stay in France after I have graduated?
output: Yes, after graduation, you can apply for APS (autorisation provisoire de séjour), which allows you to stay in France. The stay-back duration varies by nationality.

instruction: When do classes start?
output: Classes start in October each year. All information related to registration will be provided during the first weeks of study.

instruction: What is the best way to have an acceptance? Does the embassy give them the student visa directly for 2 years? Do you need another residence permit made in France?
output: After applying, students receive a first acceptance letter, pay €500 as the first installment, then get the definitive admission letter for the visa. Once in France, the student organizes a meeting with the French immigration services.

instruction: On arrival in France are they greeted at the airport, train station, or other?
output: Yes, a taxi comes to pick them up at the Alès and Nîmes train stations to take them to the student residence.

instruction: How to know if I’m eligible?
output: To be eligible for the Master Disaster program, you must hold a 4-year Bachelor of Science degree or have 10 years of industry experience. English proficiency is also required.

instruction: Where and when do I find the application information for the master program?
output: Applications are open from January to September each year. You can apply online at https://msc.mines-telecom.asia. The final deadline is September 10.

instruction: Do I need a visa?
output: Yes, a student visa is required. Once you receive your acceptance letter, you can start the visa application process, which takes 15-25 days. Be sure to prove you have sufficient funds for your stay.

instruction: Are there scholarships?
output: Yes, scholarships for accommodation (housing and food) are available. The admission office can provide additional information.

instruction: What are the fees?
output: The standard fees for 24 months are €15,000 for non-EU students and €10,000 for EU students. The first payment is due within one month of the provisional acceptance letter.

instruction: Does the university accept alternative qualifications (professional experience) for master program degree courses?
output: Yes, the admission board accepts 10 years of professional experience for eligibility. However, the MSc Disaster Management includes some math and science-related coursework.

instruction: Is a year in industry part of the course (internship)?
output: Yes, the Master Disaster Management includes a mandatory 6-month internship during the second year. This can be completed in France or abroad.

instruction: I want to upload the document on the IMT platform, what file type of document is required?
output: When uploading your application, the required documents include: recent photograph, passport copy, CV, high school certificate, Bachelor’s degree, transcripts, syllabi, and two letters of recommendation.

instruction: Am I required to submit proof of funding before I submit my candidature?
output: Yes, by the end of August, you need to provide proof of available funds for your stay, such as a bank statement or a letter from a sponsor.

instruction: How do I receive and accept my confirmation letter?
output: The acceptance letter will be sent via email after the first payment.

instruction: Can I defer my admission?
output: Yes, you can defer your admission for one year. However, after one deferral, your admission will no longer be valid.

instruction: When is the next intake?
output: The next intake begins in October.

instruction: Can I do an internship during my stay in Alès (between year 1 and 2)?
output: Yes, an optional internship between year 1 and year 2 is possible. It can be proposed by IMT Mines Alès and typically lasts 2 months, with a stipend of around €500 per month.
